paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: The key question is whether TRAPPIST-1 b retains any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: TRAPPIST-1 b Observations
datasets_or_cohorts.description: JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve measuring thermal variation.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Null Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Bare-rock, no-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution used as a null baseline.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model with significant greenhouse gas absorption used for comparison.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Oxidized composition with weaker CO2 signature constraints used in model comparisons.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
